content: My maternal grandfather passed away when I was little. He has been such an important person in my life: he taught me my very first words (ironically enough, it wasn’t my father or mother), he cared for me, played with me when my parents were busy with my younger siblings, and he always encouraged me and lifted me up—he never, ever abandoned me or scolded me. In short, I think you could say he was my entire childhood. But he had an extremely egregious habit—smoking. He would smoke every day, anytime, anywhere, even though we tried to talk him out of it. That, and the fact that he was already old—he was over 70 at the time—added up to a terrible stroke as he was crossing the street to get to our house. He collapsed and never stood again. The only thing we found in his pocket was a bag of black candy, flavored with Northern Vietnam herbs—my favorite. So when I read this post, it got straight to my heart from the headline and I couldn’t stop the tears from spilling down my cheeks however hard I tried. I can relate to the pain and the sadness you’ve had to experience, and I sincerely express my sympathy. However, meanwhile, you’ve inspired me to spread the word about the most unforgettable person in my life. Thank you so much, Dan. May you always love and be loved.
